hints_html:
Try to run through an algorithm when you want to take a derivative. Ask yourself “Is this a derivative I just’know’?”. If not, ask yourself “Is there a special rule that I can use?”

For this problem, the quotient rule is your friend. The statement is

\(\frac{d}{dx}\bigg(\frac{f(x)}{g(x)} \bigg) = \frac{f'(x)g(x) - g'(x)f(x)}{g(x)^{2}}\)

provided \(f(x)\) and \(g(x)\) are differentiable and \(g(x) \neq 0\).
hints_latex:
Try to run through an algorithm when you want to take a derivative. Ask
yourself ``Is this a derivative I just'know'?''. If not, ask yourself
``Is there a special rule that I can use?''

For this problem, the quotient rule is your friend. The statement is

$\frac{d}{dx}\bigg(\frac{f(x)}{g(x)} \bigg) = \frac{f'(x)g(x) - g'(x)f(x)}{g(x)^{2}}$

provided $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ are differentiable and $g(x) \neq 0$.
hints_raw:
Try to run through an algorithm when you want to take a derivative. Ask yourself "Is this a derivative I just 'know'?". If not, ask yourself "Is there a special rule that I can use?"
For this problem, the quotient rule is your friend. The statement is

<math>
\frac{d}{dx}\bigg(\frac{f(x)}{g(x)} \bigg) = \frac{f'(x)g(x) - g'(x)f(x)}{g(x)^{2}}
</math>

provided <math> f(x) </math> and <math> g(x) </math> are differentiable and <math>g(x) \neq 0 </math>.
question: 1 (d)
sols_html:
To use the quotient rule we first identify the numerator \(f(x) = e^{x}\) and the denominator \(g(x) = x^{2} -3\). Then we calculate \(f'(x) = e^x\) and \(g'(x) = 2x\). The rest is a walk in the park, just plug it in:

\[\begin{aligned} &\frac{d}{dx}\bigg(\frac{e^{x}}{x^{2}-3}\bigg)\\ &= \frac{e^x(x^2-3)-2x(e^x)}{(x^2-3)^2} \\ &= \frac{e^{x}(x^{2}-3 - 2x)}{(x^{2}-3)^{2}}\\ &= \frac{e^{x}(x-3)(x+1)}{(x^{2}-3)^{2}}\end{aligned}\]
